section.title: Domain And Range Errors
section.para: VSIPL does not specify the behavior for domain and range errors for scalar functions. The result is implementation dependent. As such, domain and range error reporting via the ANSI C errno mechanism is implementation dependent,

section.title: Notes To Implementors
section.para: Where the prototype specification of a functions states:
A compliant implementation is required to implement at least one floating point data type (float, double, and long double). It is up to the implementation which floating point types it supports.
Similarly,

requires at least one integer data type (short int, int, long int, unsigned short int, unsigned int, unsigned long int. [long long int, unsigned long long int]
long long int is not an ANSI type, but is acceptable as a VSIPL precision suffix of _ie64, _if64, _il64 (or _ie128, _if128, _il128 or whatever is appropriate). ).

The following tables indicate how the VSIPL scalar functions correspond with the current ANSI C standard, as well as the proposed ANSI C9x draft. While draft standards are fickle things, subject to many changes, most of the current C compilers already support all of the C9x real scalar functions that are cited in the table.
The error handling requirements for VSIPL scalar functions are non specified. Thus it would be acceptable to implement scalar functions with defines.
section.programlisting: #define vsip_acos_d acos #ifdef HAVE_C9X_MATH_FLOAT #define vsip_acos_f acosf #else #define vsip_acos_f (float)acos #endif
section.para: Better still, if your system has an ANSI C compiler that supports an inline extension:
This eliminates confusion with debugging caused by the function name substitution.

section.title: Real Scalar Functions
section.para: ANSI C9x plans to extend C with a complex type. While it is too early to be certain, we expect vsip_cscalar_d (vsip_cscalar_f) to be compatible with complex double (complex float).

section.title: Real Scalar Functions
section.para: The VSIPL real scalar functions are provided for two purposes.

listitem.para: VSIPL requires extensive error checking in development mode. However, the requirements for error detection and handling for scalar functions has not been defined at this time. The VSIPL real scalar functions provide a mechanism to implement such error detection and handling requirements, if and when they are specified.

ANSI C only defines the functions in the standard C Math library for double. VSIPL defines the real scalar functions for all the floating types the implementation supports (_f reserves the name space for float, double, and long double).

section.title: vsip_acos_p
section.para: Computes the principal radian value [0, π] of the arc cosine of a scalar.

listitem.para: Input outside the range [-1, 1] is a domain error. Results of inputs outside this range are implementation dependent.
vsip_asin_p, vsip_atan_p, vsip_atan2_p, vsip_cos_p, vsip_sin_p, and vsip_tan_p

section.para:
Computes the principal radian value
-
π
/
2
π
/
2
of the arc sine of a scalar.

listitem.para:
Input outside the range
-
1
1
is a domain error. Results of inputs outside this range are implementation dependent.
vsip_acos_p, vsip_atan_p, vsip_atan2_p, vsip_cos_p, vsip_sin_p, and vsip_tan_p

section.title: vsip_atan_p
section.para:
Computes the principal radian value
-
π
/
2
π
/
2
of the Arctangent of a scalar.

listitem.para: vsip_acos_p, vsip_asin_p, vsip_atan2_p, vsip_cos_p, vsip_sin_p, and vsip_tan_p

section.title: vsip_atan2_p
section.para:
Computes the four quadrant radian value
π
π
of the arc tangent of the ratio of two scalars.

listitem.para: The rules for calculating vsip_atan2_p are the same as for the ANSI C math function atan2. The following table may be used to calculate atan2, although other methods may also be used.
The domain of vsip_atan2_p(x, y) is not valid for both x and y zero, and the result is implementation dependent.
vsip_acos_p, vsip_asin_p, vsip_atan_p, vsip_atan2_p, vsip_cos_p, vsip_sin_p, vsip_tan_p, vsip_hypot_p, and vsip_arg_p
The function vsip_hypot_p is related to vsip_atan2_p in the same way as rectangular to polar conversion is related through the magnitude and the argument. Another related function is vsip_arg_p.

section.title: vsip_ceil_p
section.para: Computes the ceiling of a scalar.

listitem.para: Returns the smallest integral value greater than or equal to the argument.

section.title: vsip_cos_p
section.para: Computes the cosine of a scalar angle in radians.

listitem.para: Input arguments are expressed in radians.
vsip_acos_p, vsip_asin_p, vsip_atan_p, vsip_atan2_p, vsip_sin_p, and vsip_tan_p

section.title: vsip_cosh_p
section.para: Computes the hyperbolic cosine of a scalar.

listitem.para: The maximum domain without overflow is implementation dependent.
Input arguments are expressed in radians.

section.title: vsip_exp_p
section.para: Computes the exponential of a scalar.

listitem.para: Overflow will occur if the argument is greater than the loge of the maximum representable number. If this occurs, the result is implementation dependent.
Input arguments are expressed in radians.
vsip_exp10_p, vsip_log_p, vsip_log10_p, vsip_pow_p, vsip_cexp_p, and vsip_clog_p

section.title: vsip_exp10_p
section.para: Computes the base 10 exponential of a scalar.

listitem.para: Overflow will occur if the argument is greater than the log10 of the maximum representable number. If this occurs, the result is implementation dependent.
Underflow will occur if the argument is less than the negative of the log10 of the maximum representable number. If this occurs, the result is implementation dependent.
vsip_exp_p, vsip_log_p, vsip_log10_p, vsip_pow_p, vsip_cexp_p, and vsip_clog_p

section.title: vsip_floor_p
section.para: Computes the floor of a scalar.

section.title: vsip_fmod_p
section.para: Computes the remainder of the quotient (modulo) of two scalars.

listitem.para: If y is zero, whether a domain error occurs or the function returns zero is implementation dependent.

section.title: vsip_hypot_p
section.para: Computes the square root of the sum of the squares (hypotenuse) of the two scalars.

listitem.para: vsip_atan2_p, vsip_sqrt_p, vsip_rsqrt_p, vsip_hypot_p, and vsip_csqrt_p
This function is related to atan2 (in the Elementary Math section), in the same way as rectangular to polar conversion is related through the magnitude and the argument.

section.title: vsip_log_p
section.para: Computes the natural logarithm of a scalar.

listitem.para: Arguments less than or equal to zero are not in the domain of log and the result is implementation dependent.
vsip_exp_p, vsip_exp10_p, vsip_log10_p, vsip_pow_p, vsip_cexp_p, and vsip_clog_p

section.title: vsip_log10_p
section.para: Computes the base 10 logarithm of a scalar.

listitem.para: Arguments less than or equal to zero are not in the domain of log and the result is implementation dependent.
vsip_exp_p, vsip_exp10_p, vsip_log_p, vsip_pow_p, vsip_cexp_p, and vsip_clog_p

section.title: vsip_pow_p
section.para: Computes the power function of two scalars.

section.title: vsip_rsqrt_p
section.para: Computes the reciprocal square root of a scalar.

listitem.para: For reciprocal square root calculation the argument must be greater than zero to be within the domain of the function. Results for cases where the argument is less than or equal zero is implementation dependent.

section.title: vsip_sin_p
section.para: Computes the sine of a scalar angle in radians.

listitem.para: Input arguments are expressed in radians.
vsip_acos_p, vsip_asin_p, vsip_atan_p, vsip_atan2_p, vsip_cos_p, and vsip_tan_p

section.title: vsip_sinh_p
section.para: Computes the hyperbolic sine of a scalar.

listitem.para: The maximum domain without overflow is implementation dependent.

section.title: vsip_sqrt_p
section.para: Computes the square root of a scalar.

For arguments

2

π

, the tangent function has a singularity. The result of these argument values are implementation dependent.
vsip_acos_p, vsip_asin_p, vsip_atan_p, vsip_atan2_p, vsip_cos_p, and vsip_sin_p

section.title: vsip_tanh_p
section.para: Computes the hyperbolic tangent of a scalar.

section.title: Complex Scalar Functions
section.para: Since ANSI C does not currently support a “complex” data type, a minimum set of complex scalar function is needed to support complex functions.
Many of these functions are very simple and may be implemented as macros for C compilers that do not support inline functions or for C compilers that generate more efficient code from macro forms.

Macros and functions are not interchangeable. The prototypes in this manual are defined as functions to avoid the potential ambiguities of macro forms. If a function is implemented as a macro, the documentation should specify such and state any consequent restrictions.
In order to support both macro and function implementations, many have a form similar to the complex scalar addition:void vsip_CADD_f(vsip_cscalar_f a, vsip_cscalar_f b, vsip_cscalar_f *r);
A macro only version could have been specified as:vsip_CADD_f(vsip_cscalar_f a, vsip_cscalar_f b, vsip_cscalar_f r);because the macro handles the argument “r” through text replacement.
By using the first form, both the macro and function form work equally well and both macro forms generate equivalent code.
The notation for function foo:
The “r” denotes the return value of the function for both the “Return By Argument Reference” and the “Return By Return Value” forms.

section.title: vsip_cadd_p

listitem.synopsis: void vsip_CADD_f(vsip_cscalar_f a, vsip_cscalar_f b, vsip_cscalar_f *r); void vsip_RCADD_f(vsip_scalar_f a, vsip_cscalar_f b, vsip_cscalar_f *r);
vsip_cscalar_f vsip_cadd_f(vsip_cscalar_f a, vsip_cscalar_f b); vsip_cscalar_f vsip_rcadd_f(vsip_scalar_f a, vsip_cscalar_f b);

listitem.para: Pointer to output sum - complex scalar
The return by argument reference forms may be implemented as macros and may have restrictions on their usage.

section.title: vsip_rect_p

listitem.synopsis: void vsip_RECT_f(vsip_scalar_f radius, vsip_scalar_f theta, vsip_cscalar_f *r);
void vsip_cscalar_f vsip_rect_f(vsip_scalar_f radius, vsip_scalar_f theta);

listitem.para: Pointer to output – complex scalar in rectangular form
Returns complex scalar in rectangular form.
The return by argument reference form may be implemented as a macro and may have restrictions on its usage.
In VSIPL, complex numbers are always in rectangular (Cartesian) format. The polar form is represented by two real scalars.

section.title: vsip_matindex
section.para: Form a matrix index from two vector indices.

listitem.synopsis: void vsip_MATINDEX(vsip_scalar_vi row, vsip_scalar_vi col, vsip_scalar_mi *r);

listitem.para: Note to implementors: since VSIPL does not specify what the base integer type is; the arguments must be of type vsip_scalar_vi, which in an unsigned integer type sufficient to index the largest supported vector.

section.title: vsip_mcolindex
section.para: Returns the column vector index from a matrix index.

section.title: vsip_mrowindex
section.para: Returns the row vector index from a matrix index.

section.title: vsip_tenindex
section.para: Form a tensor index from three vector indices.

listitem.synopsis: void vsip_TENINDEX(vsip_scalar_vi z, vsip_scalar_vi y, vsip_scalar_vi x, vsip_scalar_ti *r);
vsip_scalar_ti vsip_tenindex(vsip_scalar_vi z, vsip_scalar_vi y, vsip_scalar_vi x);

section.title: vsip_txindex
section.para: Returns the x index from a tensor index.

section.title: vsip_tyindex
section.para: Returns the y index from a tensor index.

section.title: vsip_tzindex
section.para: Returns the z index from a tensor index.
